data.title: haley lauren travels
data.text:
It’s officially more than halfway through the semester, and officially spring! Spring’s got me feeling all sorts of giddy this year. And Switzerland is just as beautiful snow-less as it is snow-covered. And, for students, spring obviously means Spring Break! Except here, the proper term is “Easter Holiday.” You can certainly say spring break, but I’d discourage you from doing so unless you want to get suggestive and funny looks from whomever you’re telling, as when they hear these words together they think of girls gone wild and alcohol poisoning. Anyway, my break in the spring this year is completely immeasurable to every year’s past, as I spent it wandering to and around Stockholm, Sweden and Barcelona, Spain.

I started off last Saturday (4/3/2014) in Stockholm. But hold your horses everyone. Public service announcement: I have found the most amazing gelateria in Milan. How are these related you say? Well I had to ride the train to Milan first –> bus it to the airport –> fly it to Stockholm –> bus it to the city –> before I could make my fabulous appearance down those cobblestone streets. Anyway, the gelato! The place is called GELATERIA SARTORI. When you exit Milano Centrale train station, turn left where all the airport buses pick up. Keep walking to the back corner of the building until you find the cart nestled against the side of the building. And order pistachio. (I am a new fan of pistachio, but theirs is also unlike anything I’ve ever had.) I stopped here on my outward and return journeys- both times I was the only non-local ordering.

STOCKHOLM (4/4/2015) – I took the cheap RyanAir flight, so I didn’t actually arrive to my hostel until about 1am. But the next morning (4/5/2015) I was up and ready to go- Easter Sunday and there were still a bunch of shops and stores open! I spent most of the morning exploring the area by foot (and picking out a couple new clothing pieces from H&M..) before eating lunch from a highly recommended herring food truck by the industrial area. It is called NYSTEKT STROMMING, and for 75 SEK (about 8 bucks) you get an order of fresh herring, mashed potatoes, cole slaw, pickled onions, and pickled cucumbers. Delicious! Oh, and did I mention that Stockholm is actually made up of 14 different islands? You are always walking over a bridge of some sort..! And then in addition to these islands there are a bunch more smaller archipelagos that spread across Lake Malaren until it feeds into the Baltic Sea. A few of the islands out there are inhabited year-round, but they don’t truly become a destination tourist attraction until about the end of May.

After wondering around the different parts of Stockholm (historic, business district, industrial/hipster) I took the metro out of the city center cluster to SKOGSKYRKOGARDEN, or the WOODLAND CEMETERY. I know, it’s a little bit weird to head out to a cemetery the first day I get to Stockholm. But the cemetery was designed by famous architects Gunnar Asplund and Sigurd Lewerentz, and was brought to fruition between 1917 and 1940. I had seen absolutely breathtaking photos of the landscape architecture before arriving, and was not disappointed. Approaching 6pm on a semi-rainy and mostly cloudy day, the cemetery had this beautiful aura about it, and was subject to moments of the gorgeous yellow light softly radiating and peeping out around the grey clouds.

I took the metro back into the city and headed back toward my hostel, which was amazing! The name of the hostel is CITY BACKPACKERS. Wonderfully located, friendly staff and well-kept facilities made for an enjoyable stay. Only in a Swedish hostel would they make you take off your shoes before entering (Swedish custom) and also have a conveniently sauna located next to the showers. I ended meeting up with a girl from New Jersey in my room, and we headed out to find dinner together. It’s always nice to find some travel buddies! After dinner at a yummy Thai place we went out to for a couple drinks on the town. And let me tell ya something, Stockholm’s drinks out are NOT cheap! For one (nice) beer, it costs about 85-90 SEK! (That’s about 10 bucks.) So blah blah, live music and some crazy drunk people, we decide to get a hot dog from a stand that’s open really late. This guy has the hot dogs that range over four degrees of spicy, and I took the second. It was so yummy! But.. we also ended up trying a bite of the 4th degree (you have to sign a waver and everything, and eat the whole thing in under 5 minutes in order to win a tshirt..) and it was miserable!! At first I thought it tasted good, but after just one bite my whole mouth was on fire, and beer in water in amount were not helping. I think my mouth was still burning the next morning.

But it was all okay because I was headed to the Swedish spa! (4/6/2015) I signed up for one online at STUREBADET, and hopped over there for my massage appointment in the morning. The facilities were, of course, beautiful. The spa was created in 1885 by Carl Curman, described as a “doctor and Renaissance man” according to their website. The wood and marble construction was picture-perfect, and beyond relaxing. I did observe and notice that the “luxurious” appeal of participating in a spa day to most Americans (I think) is something that is completely normal, necessary, and routine for a Swede. They definitely don’t get massages every day, but they definitely do go here and swim, socialize, and relax on a normal basis. I would really view this experience as cultural more than anything. It was really neat to see residents of the city going about their daily routines, and realizing that my spa morning was just another aspect of their every-day.

For lunch, I went to a local burger place I had read about online, for a low-cost, delicious lunch! At VIGARDA, I ordered the traditional burger, which came with chili, cheddar, BBQ, and a yummy sauce. Walk walk walk, explore explore explore and I met up with my Jersey friend again to go for a drink and the ever-so-touristy viking restaurant! I recommend WIRSTROMS PUB, mostly for the comfy-cosy atmosphere and good selection of beer. The viking restaurant was an experience, that’s for sure. AIFUR KROG & BAR is in a basement off the main street in old town, accented with dim lighting, fur seating, and crude eating utensils. It was a fun atmosphere! The waitresses seemed unhappy with their jobs (or maybe they were just playing the part of the grumpy viking??) but the food and experience was still well worth it, I’d say. For the more adventurous they offered deer and some over gamey meats, but I stuck with chicken and a what barley salad. So yummy!

Breakfast the next morning was to be had at VETE-KATTEN. The Swedish are famous for their cinnamon buns, so I tried one of those with a latte. (By the way, Swedish are also big on coffee. They have their own vocabulary word for coffee break (mid-afternoon), which is fika!)

{{OH GUYS. I need a moment to tell you some terrible news. The Ice Bar in Stockholm was one of my main points of interest this trip. Come on, a whole bar made of ice?? Even the cups?? So cool! I don’t care if it’s touristy. Turns out they were replacing the ice in the ice bar over the course of a week, and I happened to be there 4 days out of the 7 they were doing this. And this only happens once a year.. I will admit I was in a small state of depression after hearing this news.}}

This day (4/7/2014) I hopped over to the MODERNA MUSEET, where they were showcasing exhibitions by Louise Bourgeois (French graphic artist and sculpltor) and Akram Zaatari (Lebanese photographer and film artist). Both were extremely intense in their respective ways. Bourgeois’ exhibition itself was named “I have been to hell and back,” which is pulled from one of her graphic works where the second part of the piece optimistically cries, “And let me tell you, it was wonderful.” In the informational booklet, I think the writer appropriately states that the images and sculptures that make up the artist’s works are “unstable and searching,” and frighteningly beautiful. Zaatari’s work is concentrated in the art of subjectively composing existing images in order to tell/ show a history. The archival and subjective nature of the pieces that create a larger composition are stunning, and reminds me of a sort of typological study, similar to Bernd and Hilla Becher’s work.

I wondered over to the central market for lunch, called OSTERMALMS SALUHALL. A bunch of local vendors were selling meats, cheeses, etc. I grabbed the potato pancakes with bacon from a local cafe inside, which is a typical traditional dish of Sweden. Really just so yummy.

I then proceeded to the island of DJURGARDEN, and walked around this beautiful park-eqsue landscape, laced with museums, houses, historical palaces, and restaurants. I stopped by the ROSENDAL PALACE, built for a Swedish King in the 1820’s. The most interesting part of the palace complex, though, was the garden! A fully operating garden (ROSENDALS TRADGARD) also services a cafe, with beautiful little snacks and treats. I just tried a couple cookies and ate them in the garden- it was lovely 🙂

I then took part in the free walking tour of the historic area, where I learned some more about the history of Stockholm, how you could tell how old the buildings really were in “old” town, why drinks are so expensive in Sweden (there was a bad period of alcoholism and economics a while back before the Swedes became a well-off country), the story about the war ship Vasa from the 1600’s, which was elaborately constructed, but not elaborately engineered, and sunk in its first 10 minutes of sailing from the harbor. It was just salvaged from the bottom of the lake in the 1960s!! Among some other interesting histories related to the city!

For dinner, the hostel staff recommended TRANAN to me for my taste of the famous Swedish meatballs. If you sit in the bar area, it’s less expensive, and the bartending staff was so friendly and sweet! The meatballs (served with mashed potatoes, lingonberries, and pickled cucumbers) were out of this world amazing. I need to find a recipe so I can try to recreate this delicious traditional dish.

4/8/2015 was my switching day! Stockholm to BARCELONA. But I of course managed to eat some more before I left.. I got some coffee from DROP COFFEE and a small pastry in the Soder region before I left. Cute huh?

So I arrived in Barcelona around 7pm. Let me start this part of the story off by saying: Barcelona has been my favorite European city I’ve ever been to. Navigating to the hostel was super easy, and Barcelona public transport is perfect. I never spent more than 2 minutes waiting for a metro. Anyway, at HOSTELONE PARALELO, I was truly at home. The owner, Angel, is the sweetest, funniest man, and is more than happy to give you the low-down on the city- what’s worth seeing and what’s not, and how to make the most of your time in this beautiful, beautiful place. Every night, the hostel cooks dinner for free, (tips encouraged) and it’s always something local. Everyone eats together like one big family, and you get to know your other hostel mates over some beer and sangria. The hostel also takes everyone out, and it was so comforting being with a local who can show you around and help you get your bearings.

My day 4/9/2015 started off with a bang at the unfinished masterpiece of the SAGRADA FAMILIA. Designed by Antoni Gaudi, this beautiful church has been a work in progress since 1882. The sheer scale of the building as a whole in comparison to its surroundings is breathtaking, but the experience inside it is a complete other thing. I just felt lifted when I walked in, like maybe someone was slightly pushing my feet from under me as I was walking around. I spent a whole hour circling the church, exiting and re-entering. It never got boring.

I spent the afternoon walking around PARC GUELL, but not actually entering. (Barcelona is not a crazy expensive city, but admission to all of the Gaudi works and museums certainly is!) I still got some gorgeous views of the city and sea from above, which certainly sufficed. On my way back to the center, I stumbled across a cute tshirt printing company, designed and made in Barcelona. I couldn’t resist this cute tshirt!

Along the main shopping center, La Rambla, you will find the best thing that’s ever happened to me, or the MERCADO DE LA BOQUERIA. The open-air market was everything I could dream of and more- fresh dried meats and hams, Spanish cheeses, fresh fruit juices, a bunch of fried seafood, and so much more. (Btw wall the pictures are from two trips on two different days, I’m bad at self-control but not that bad!!)

I re-fueled at the hostel, and was out again to the PICASSO MUSEUM, which was so so neat! Anytime I’m in a museum and see a Picasso piece it always seems like a little isolated jewel, but it was great to be able to see his work over the span of a lifetime- how it changed and evolved, and how he worked in terms of process. They also had a contemporary exhibit on display, which was essentially the juxtaposition of Picasso’s works with Salvador Dali’s works (even though Dali was born 20 years after Picasso). This juxtaposition makes you aware of how much they influenced each other, and similar themes or ideas they were trying to convey. If anyone’s interested to know more, here is a WSJ article about the exhibition.

http://www.wsj.com/articles/a-relationship-fraught-and-fruitful-on-picasso-dali-dali-picasso-at-the-dali-museum-1419982238

Then, I met up with one of my friends in my sorority who is studying in Barcelona this semester. Like I said earlier, it’s so nice to meet up with people! I love having the days to explore stuff at my own pace and the nights to meet people and socialize. She took us to a local tapas bar, LA LUNA, where we had delicious white sangria, and I ordered patatas bravas (essentially potato wedges with a yummy white sauce) and a Spanish cheese plate. We also made our way to a local gin bar called the LIME HOUSE for some yummy mojitos! It was so nice to spend time with a familiar face!

My second and final full day in Barcelona, I made my way to PALAU ROBERT, which is currently housing an exhibition on a local architecture firm named RCR. The exhibition was nice- there were several main themes, like meditation with the landscape, public and social function, the presence of time, etc. And so many models! This was also free- so that made my wallet happy.

Along this street, Passeig de Gràcia, three of Gaudi’s houses notably stand out from the rest of the architectural language. I walked by them all, but took a tour of CASA BATLLO. Built 1904-06, the house, especially the facade, is reminiscent of water, sea creatures, and nature-esque forms. The audio tour was amazing- each room was explained from its function down to the ventilation details in the doors. It does a really good job at giving you insight to Gaudi’s thinking and formal execution of ideas.

I strolled down this street until I began to reach the harbor. Before continuing, though, I stopped for a sandwich at BO DE B. This is a famous sandwich shop, mostly among tourists, but that doesn’t mean locals don’t go there or that it wasn’t absolutely delicious. I got the hamburger sandwich, with all the sauces. Yum yum! And I was actually really lucky, because there was only one person waiting outside the door when I got there. Apparently, there is always a line that’s snaking around the corner of the street.

With a full and satisfied tummy, I walked to and along the beach, grabbing a mojito and taking in the beautiful sea and sunny rays for the rest of the afternoon.

At night, I ate beans and risotto with my hostel, and went out with the group! Again, so fun. Shots bars and clubs galore. We ended up staying out til about 3, which is early, because I had to wake up in 3 hours to catch the early flight back to Milano!

Once in Milan, I had enough time to eat lunch there, and did so at PIZZA BIG. Where, you guessed it, they had big pizza! (But again, really thin.) This was delicious, and I would definitely go again. Just a couple blocks from the central station. Obviously, I stopped by Gelateria Sartori for some pistachio. And if you haven’t noticed by my pictures, food experiences are equally important to me as buildings/ sightseeing/ etc. I mean, it’s a part of the culture! Being immersed in the food realm is one of the best ways to get to know a place, and people for that matter!

But while waiting outside the station, basking in the sun, I reflected on just how lucky I am to have this opportunity to live in Europe. Just living in Switzerland was a big step, but now I’m independently traveling to other countries, navigating cities, and experiencing other cultures, all on my own?? Of course it wouldn’t be possible without my mom and Steve! Life can be pretty wonderful. And I have another Brian Andreas quote.. you guys know how obsessed I am. He just recently posted this one on his Instagram:

“I had no idea that when I invited Life to take over that it actually would & now I’m somewhere miles away from any place I know & Life keeps waiving its arms & grinning like a crazy person saying This. Is. So. Great.”

^^how’s the guy so good at words?? 🙂

xxxoo Haley

Wow!!! It’s already more than the middle of March. I should just stop commentating on how fast time passes. (Thankful I have 5 years in college instead of 4!) And no! I did not make up a new word. Ouagadougou is the capital of Burkina Faso, and it is our site for this semester’s program. Diébédo Francis Kéré is my professor this semester, originally from Burkina Faso but educated in architecture in Berlin. He works largely in the vernacular context, creating educational and public buildings in rural Burkina Faso. This is his website: http://www.kerearchitecture.com/

And also a TED talk (obsessed with these by the way) on building with local materials: https://www.ted.com/talks/diebedo_francis_kere_how_to_build_with_clay_and_community

He really is such an inspiring person. Anyway, our project this semester is a new parliament building for Ouagadougou, as theirs was actually burned down in political riots in October. Blaise Compaore was the president for 27 years, and in his attempt to extend his term an uprising among the Burkinabe people resulted in the demolition of the parliament building, as well as his rule.

So that was the start to my semester! Usually, the Kéré studio travels to Burkina and participates in a “building workshop” in which the project of the studio is brought to actual realization. Because of the political instability, and also the scale of the project, we were unable to travel to Africa. However, we did go to NAPLES! Here, we participated in a dome-building workshop in a small town 1.5 hours outside of the city, in a small town called SAN POTITO.

But before that I managed to make it to Milano twice! (Side note: I used to always say Milan. Or Naples for example. But since living here for so long, I find myself using both. At first I found it “fancy” or excessive to say Milano or Napoli. Right or wrong, that’s just how I felt when I said it! But now it comes naturally both ways. I think it’s an interesting observation.)

The first time: I went with a few of the people I live with in the casa. It was a leisurely day, and we walked around and saw some architecture! Three buildings + aperitivo afterward = perfect day! (P.s. I’m obsessed with the store MUJI. This Japanese department-like store has everything, and so nicely designed! Their pens are the greatest things I have ever held. Too bad they only have it in NYC in the states.)

School, school, etc. etc.

(3/10/2015) I found myself again in Milan with my best friend!! My little in my sorority visited me for the couple days before my departure to Naples- I am so lucky! (We also went to Como.) I loved being a tourist in Milan. I know this city kind of well, actually. Definitely better than I know Washington D.C.! I’ve also been to Milan more times than I’ve been to D.C. I think… Anyway, whenever I go with my exchange friends, we do fun, off-the-beaten path things. I’ve never gotten to be the silly tourist! Gigi’s presence was the perfect excuse. We climbed to the top of the Duomo, ate delicious panzerotti at LUINI (all the locals go here, as well), grabbed gelato at GELATERIA GROM, fed some pigeons (so fun!!!!), meandered over to CASTELLO SFORZESCO, drank a beer (and ate cotton candy) in PARCO SEMPIONE, shopped along the Navigli Canal, and had aperitivo at my favorite bar! It was near perfect.

So, Naples!

Day 1 (2/11/2015) was mostly spent traveling. We took the train from Milan. Upon arrival however, we stopped for coffee at THE BEST place just outside the train station. (Now there are actually many, but this was the first.) It’s called MEXICO. Yeah, yeah sounds a bit sketchy, Mexico in Napoli? Trust me. Best. Coffee. Ever. Along with pastries and donuts…

Anyway after an espresso we hop over to L’ ANTICA PIZZERIA DA MICHELE, supposedly the best pizza in all of Napoli. When I looked it up to make sure I spelled it right, I discovered that Eat, Pray, Love was filmed here, and that Julia Roberts sat in this very establishment! Anyway, they only serve two types of pizza. Get the double mozzarella if you go. A huge (albeit very thin-crusted, that’s why it’s justified to eat the whole thing of course) pizza and a beer for only 7 euros. Am I in paradise?

We stayed the night in HOSTEL OF THE SUN, which was so nice! The staff was so pleasant and the rooms were clean, as well as the bathrooms. I wish we could have stayed longer here, but the next day we were up and at ‘em to head to San Potitio! (Coffee from Mexcio before the 1.5 hour bus drive was absolutely necessary, obviously.)

We were welcomed by our hosts, Fabrizio Carola, and crew. He is an architect that focuses on a specific type of dome-building technique, and we were there to learn and build for 2 days. There is a man-made “compass” in the very center of the dome-to-be, and you simply move the compass to measure the angle at which you will place the next brick. Start from bottom and go until you hit roof!

Oh, and also- you’d expect it to be warming up in on of the southernmost parts of Italy in the middle of March, right? Wrong. So guess who packed light and forgot her jacket? This gal. Oh well, what doesn’t kill ya makes ya stronger. It wasn’t so bad.

Then, we had two nights left in Naples. It was my prerogative to EAT. Unsurprisingly, I fulfilled (filled! punny, get it??) this task, going above and beyond the call of duty. I wouldn’t be surprised if those reading the account of all my eats would feel as though they instantly gained five pounds. Okay, so let’s get to it. The first night back we checked in at our airbnb apartment (gorgeous by the way!!) and went in search for food on a Friday night in Naples. Our airbnb host told us the name of a good restaurant nearby called TRATTORIA DA NENNELLA. Apparently it’s just a fact of the game that you always wait an hour/ 1.5 hours before getting seated anywhere for dinner on the weekend. In our wait time, we grabbed a beer and tried a local street food called taralli. It’s like a cracker, but seasoned and so good! Once in the restaurant, I was amazed to find that an appetizer, pasta, and side was all only 12 euros. It’s one thing that the food was so heavenly, but another that it was so cheap! This place was also the definition of those cheesy Italian shows. You know, like the one in Matilda where the family is eating dinner and they make Matilda watch people covered in sticky stuff trying to get the flying money to stick to them and they win it? Maybe you don’t… anyway there was no flying money but a lot of suggestive dancing and undressing of bananas. This table next to of us of about 12 ladies found it hilarious. Why?? I will never know, but it certainly was entertaining. And the food was perfect.

That night, we headed out to the university district for a few drinks. It was pretty low key, but nice to explore nonetheless! Napoli is full of crazed moped drivers, crazed regular drivers, and is a little dirty. But what it lacks in these departments is definitely compensated for by the food and charm. It reminded me of a crazier Rome.

Saturday (03/14/2015), we had a full schedule on our hands! It started off with a guided tour of Naples’ underground, which was so neat! Forty feet below ground, we walked through and around a system of aqueducts and walkways that were constructed thousands of years ago. During WWII, though, the carved underground was used as a bomb shelter for the Napoletanos. There was one really narrow and unlit path, for which we grabbed a candle and climbed through the slimmest of openings by flickering light. I loved it. We also visited an ancient Greek theater, which actually wasn’t even discovered until recently. After the war, it was rebuilt on as an apartment complex! Imagine finding out you were living on top of an ancient Greek theater.. Crazy!

Next, we went to PIO DELLA MISERICORDIA, where there is a famous painting by Caravaggio called the Seven Works of Mercy. The seven works were actually meant to be seven paintings to be hung on the interior of the church, but they were all combined into one painting to sit at the altar instead. An American artist named Laddie John Dill was there to officially open his exhibition for his sculptures, which serve as modes of interpretation for Caravaggio’s painting.

Next, we headed to MUSEO MADRE, a modern art museum. It was interesting that the 19th century palazzo in which the museum is located is also home to all of these modern art pieces. Alvaro Siza (Portuguese architect) renovated the museum’s interior in 2005, so the building itself was also neat to be in!

Lunch (ish) was comprised of fried pizza, fried pasta, more pizza, and sfogliatelle (pastry with sweet ricotta cheese and citrus flavor). Street food is the best food.

We then visited CHAPEL SANSEVERO, which was absolutely amazing. There are a bunch of late-Baroque sculptures of marble housed here, the most renowned being the Veiled Christ by Giuseppe Sanmartino in 1753. You can’t stop staring, Im serious. You almost feel that the body under the cloth is breathing, it seems so alive. All of the other sculptures were equally captivating in their own ways. The floor of the chapel, though, was one of my favorite things. It was designed by Francesco Celabrano (1765). How could something so flat, sculpted from such a heavy material, seem to be pulsating with such life? Much different than the sculpted marble, of course, in its own way. I really loved staring at all this stone stuff for an hour.

We made our way up to CERTOSA DI SAN MARTINO as the sun was beginning to set. Formerly a monastery and now a museum, we didn’t have too much time here. But the views of Naples from above were breathtaking.

Then we made our way back down for…. food!! We ate as a big group at PIZZERIA STARITA A MATERDEI. When you eat as a big group in an Italian restaurant you don’t pick what you want, rather they bring out popular and local dishes for everyone to share. And they keep bringing.. and bringing… and bringing… more food. This is meal was insane, I think I ate my actual body weight in fried dough. But don’t think for a second that I didn’t love every second of it!!

For our last night in Naples, we headed back to the same university district area and ended up staying out till 5 am!! People in Europe are so unfazed by staying out in the wee hours of the morning. It’s something I’ve had to adjust to. Nothing special though, just good beer and good company in a beautiful city! Bonus: I was starving on the way back to the apartment and a kebab place was open! What are the odds? Falafel for one, please.

The next day, I managed to buy some necessities to bring home. No souveneirs, no tshirts. You guess it: FOOD! Do I have a food complex or something? I just love it so much. I got a bunch of taralli to take back, as well as fresh buffalo mozzarella, pasta, and limoncello. The staples of Italy, from the best of the best.

And in between shopping for food I treated myself to gelato.

And now, we have one meal left! It just so worked out that the last really was the best. We ate at ANTICA LATTERIA, which was suggested to our group by someone from the area. This meal wasn’t as cheap, but I will dream about it for years to come. For appetizer, I had fish meatballs (it sounds weird but it’s essentially fancy fish sticks), and for the main course, gnocchi with octopus. I was a little adventurous here because Naples is right next to the sea, and I figured I’d branch out. I never wanted my bites to end.

And that was Napoli! I commenced wallowing in my extra 10 pound body on the pacifying (as always) train ride back. And worth every ounce.

The school week passed, as it usually does – fast. And I found myself again in Milan last night with some friends from the casa! Did I mention I love Milan? We went to the TUNNEL CLUB for a concert by a man named Franceso Tristano. Electronic music, flashing lights, and staying out till 6 A.M. took it to whole new level for me. I had the best time! Oh, and before, we went to a bar called BAR MOGAMO. I loved this place! Great mojitos and good atmosphere. I want to go back. (I’m sure that won’t be a problem.)

And I have to tell a funny anecdote that just happened. I am still exhausted from my sleepless night in Milan, and one of my friends from Portugal stopped by my apartment to ask if I was going to join the small birthday celebration next door. I told him I was still so tired and going to bed soon (after I finish writing this) and he was like, “Oh, okay. Rest well! I was going to say rest in peace but I don’t think it’s okay to say…?” This made me laugh a lot. Living with friends from all over the world has honestly and easily been one of the best experiences I’ve been lucky enough to be a part of.

Oh aaand.. drumroll please! I am traveling all by super super big girl self to Stockholm, Sweden and Barcelona, Spain for spring break in a couple weeks! And I thought the plane ride to Switzerland by myself was a feat back in August! I love traveling with people, don’t get me wrong, but I also love being alone. Also, this way, no one can judge or prevent me from eating cake and drinking coffee for every meal. (JK… or am I?) I love Europe.

~ Haley

2/5/2015 – 2/15/2015

I’m baaaaack! In Svizzera, that is. And boy does it feel good. I really do love this place. When I landed in Zurich the security man looked at my passport and said, so you live here? At which point I said yes, and he proceeded to ask my for my resident card. I incredulously continued through the airport, thinking, why, yes, I DO live here. I was returning to a familiar place, familiar people, and a room full of my stuff in the southernmost region of Switzerland, tucked away in some mountains and Italian-esque streets. Pinch me.

And then pinch me again because my best friend was waiting for me at the airport!! Our meeting spot was McDonalds (very original I know) – where we got some overpriced coffee to deter our jet lag. We hopped on the train (the familiarity, cleanliness, and punctuality of the Swiss trains was a warm welcome in itself) from the airport to the center of Zurich. (I’m skipping over the part where we went a stop too far, had to get off at the next one, and get back on again.) The unfamiliarity of being in a big city in Switzerland (very foreign concept to me), where they have trams, was overwhelming and confusing, especially when you’re lugging around two suitcases and a purse so big you could probably fit a dog in it. Kate and I meandered over to what we now know was a refueling/ fix-it station for the trams, hoping we were in the right place to get onboard. It took about 10 minutes of half-investigating and half-blankly staring before we lugged our little American butts to an actual stop, at which point we got on a tram and annoyed everyone with our excessive baggage. But wait, it gets better! We were on the right tram, wrong direction. Take 10 – we get off and manage to redeposit ourselves on one going in the right direction toward our hotel.

We are staying at KAFI SCHNAPS, which is actually a coffee/bar with a set of rooms on the second floor. I read about this place in the Fodor Switzerland book. It was an adorable, clean, cute, and relatively cheap option for our night in Zurich. Kate and I loved it, I definitely recommend!! It’s just a few tram stops away from the city center. We go for a panini because we are starving (I refuse to eat airplane meals. They smell funny. Side note- I actually did eat an airplane meal on my journey back to the states, and it completely backfired. The weird curry chicken fell off my fork and into my fluffy infinity scarf, blessing me with a lovely scent for the duration of my travels. Never again.) Anyway, we both grabbed a veggie panini. I will make this announcement now: Switzerland is expensive!!! I do live here, but traveling was completely different. You will spend a small fortune.

We headed over to GROSSMUNSTER church, where you can pay a few francs to climb up to the top and enjoy some beautiful panoramic views of the city. And since it was absolutely freezing outside, there was hardly anyone up there! Score for us.

Next stop: a beer hall! Funny story: Kate and I kept a running list of words highlighting our experiences so I could recall everything properly. When we talked about this day, I said, “Oh! We went to the beer hall first!” and she was telling me no, that we went to the cinema themed place first for wine. I insisted on my event captioning, at which point she realized, “Oh! You mean the other beer hall we went to!” So the order of events went like this: we went to a beer hall and enjoyed a tipple among the local 50+ age group, grabbed some wine and water at a weird cinema restaurant (Switzerland – where water costs more than wine), and went to another beer hall, where we each got a healthy flight and shared a cheese plate. I think we did Zurich good. Oh, and we had an old man sitting near us at our last stop, continuously cheers-ing us and talking to us in Swiss German. The tone seemed endearing so we smiled and nodded until he bid us adieu.

Next morning – breakfast in our coffee shop/ hotel! Bread, cheese, butter, and jelly (and I don’t even really like jelly) never tasted so good.

Then we were off to Mendrisio! A couple trains later, we arrive here with a yucky sleet mix accompanying us as we made our way to the casa. After settling in a bit (and by settling in I mean not unpacking a thing) we grocery shopped and made lunch. I decided to take Kate to Como this evening for a nice aperitivo. The Swiss train got us to Chiasso (the last Swiss train stop) and told us to get off. We find out that the Italian trains must be on strike! Because they were not running. Luckily Como is bus ride-able, so we hopped on and made our way to the most adorable place called FRESCO, which was recommended to me by a friend. The cocktails and finger foods here were truly an art. it was such a nice experience! I will definitely go again. On our way home we stopped by some run-down pizza shop and grabbed a bite, joking that this must be George Clooney’s favorite pizza shop. I found it really amusing in the moment but now that I’m writing about it it seems kind of boring. Sorry if the headline disappointed anyone.

The next day we went exploring around Lugano. After reading some reviews online, we decided to eat at LA TINERA, a typical Ticinese restaurant. They’re known for their risotto, so I think you can guess what I ordered. Plus mushrooms. So filling and so yummy. In these types of restaurants they also serve wine in what look like mini bowls – so fun! This meal was a great local experience.

We then set out around the lake and to the next town to begin the SENTIERO DI GANDRIA, a scenic trail running along Lake Lugano. When we arrived in the town where the trail begins, we hopped off the bus to this old man shouting, “Hello!!! Welcome to my country!!!!” This was Clint, our new Swiss friend who continues to jabber on for approximately 15 minutes about how he loves America and stories from his childhood. Definitely a colorful character. We continue along, making our way to the path. The walk was absolutely gorgeous!! The Gandria trail also featured this neat Olive Trail, with all these informational signs about the growing and harvesting of olives. Olives are one of my favorite foods and I found it rather interesting. Olive oil is also one of my favorite foods. Olives are just a great crop overall!

On our way back to Mendrisio that night we ran into a bachelorette party, except it was weird because they were trying to get everyone (including myself and Kate) to buy airplane sized soaps and gadgets for a couple of francs. Is this normal? This would be stressful to me. Do they really end up getting a lot of money? Are these funds for the wedding? This was simply odd. Sorry Kate, we are not doing this at your bachelorette party.

That was essentially the day, and we made sure to rest up in preparation to wake up the next day and leave for LUZERN. This is also a Swiss German region of Swtizerland. We arrived here and made our way (loudly and annoyingly as we rolled our suitcases on the cobblestone streets) to the JAIL HOTEL. Yep, you heard me! This place was a prison until 1998. The location is great and the prices are cheap. And Luzern is the definition of picturesque. We grabbed a quick lunch in the train station because it was Sunday. (Practically everything in Switzerland is closed on Sundays. Except…)

the KKL LUZERN, the Luzern Culture and Convention Center. Inside is also the KUNSTMUSEUM, a modern art museum, which we partook in. The exhibits were neat! My favorite were photographs by an artist named Candida Hofer. The KKL itself was designed by Jean Nouvel, so the entire building was also really architecturally interesting to me. I loved the emergency exits!! You will see what I am talking about in a picture below.

We walked across the KAPELLBRUCKE (Chapel Bridge), a wooden bridge that crosses the Reuss River in the city center. It is the oldest covered wooden bridge in Europe! Later, we grabbed drinks at RATHAUS BRAUEREI. Good beer and good company made for a good happy hour 🙂

Next day: MT. RIGI! This is one of the major peaks in the region, also known as Queen of the Mountains. We took a boat to a small town at the bottom of the mountain, rode a cogwheel train up the entire mountain (there are no words for how beautiful this was) and found ourselves 1,800 meters above sea level, in a beautiful, snow-dusted wonderland. We wandered over to a small cottage on the mountain, to be invited in by the friendly Swiss German owner. We ordered coffee in broken German but managed! The wood cabin was so cozy and warm, and this cute cat that perched itself on the shelf of the window held my gaze almost the entire time. I love cats!! And dogs!! Once we finished de-frosting, we braved the mountain again, meandered around the souveneir shop, and caught the cogwheel half way back down the mountain, stopping in a small village where we would then take an aerial cable car back to the bottom. Here, we saw some people frolicking in a hot pool in the middle of the mountains. I later found out that (surprise, surprise) it was designed by Mario Botta. The official name of the spa is the RIGI KALTBAD MINERAL BATHS & SPA. I found a picture online (below), but this is what we saw as we were passing by! I was jealous to say the least. But the aerial cable car back down was fun as well.

Once back in Luzern, we headed over to the LION MONUMENT, which is a sculpture carved from an existing rock to commemorate Swiss guards who died in 1792 during the French Revolution. I read online that Mark Twain said something to the effect of this sculpture being the saddest and most moving piece of rock in the world. (He also wrote about the beauty of the Alps. About Weggis, {one of the villages we stopped by to get up Mt. Rigi} “I believe that this place is the lovliest in the world, and the most satisfactory. The scenery is beyond comparison beautiful… Sunday in heaven is noisy compared to this quietness.”) There is even a Mark Twain trail you can hike!

For dinner, Kate and I tried to branch out. We were unsuccessful and ended up at the Rathaus Brauerei again. (To give us some credit, we didn’t eat here the day before!) I got the chef’s plate or something to this effect, and Kate got a traditional cheesy, potatoe-y Swiss meal with some applesauce. Beyond wonderful.

The next morning we woke up early to get to GENEVA, our last stop. We did the whole Airbnb thing for here. Kate had previously asked our apartment contact when we could check in, and he said any time! So we got to our “Arty and quiet flat, close to lake” to find a man inside! He mumbled to us in French and called the owner. Apparently check-in was any time after 2. The man continues to lecture us about how, in Europe, you never check in early. We were annoyed at his degrading speech regarding check-in times, but glad that we could leave our luggage there because we had scheduled a tour at CERN! (the European Organization for Nuclear Research) {Also, the arty and quiet flat was no disappointment! We loved everything about it – location, quaintness, and the owner was super nice}

Side note: Before we went there, though, we ate lunch at CHEZ MA COUSINE, where we had the most wonderful rotisserie chicken (with this special gravy-type sauce), salad, and french fries. It was relatively cheap for the heaps of food you get, and fast!

So, CERN – there is a bus that goes all the way out to the complex, but it was taking a while because it was the very last stop. Arriving 15 minutes late, Kate and I were trying to find our way to the reception when I saw a man in a hard hat and an ID tag that had CERN written all over it. I asked him if he knew where reception was, because we were late for the 12:00 tour. He was so kind!!! He said, oh, if you go to reception they will just tell you, “Too bad!” So, he took us back to his office, looked up our tour, and took us to the part of the building where our tour group was. We were very thankful for him.

The tour was very informative, and free! Basically, CERN studies the fundamental elements that make up the universe. They have a huge, underground machine called the Large Hadron Collider that sits 100 meters below ground that creates particle collisions. The temperature inside the collider is -270 degrees Celsius! (colder than outer space!) When they run the machine, it takes 40 million 3D photographs per second of colliding particles. The computers are able to sift out uninteresting collisions, and saves the potentially “interesting” ones, which people are then able to identify and study. Ps – this is where the world wide web was invented!

They also had a neat building featuring an interactive exhibit about CERN, which is called the GLOBE OF SCIENCE AND INNOVATION. When I looked it up later I found out it was designed by Herve Dessimoz, from Groupe H Architects, with the help of a wood engineer named Thomas Buchi, from Charpente Concept. It is also apparently the tallest timber domed structure in the world! (27 meters high, 40 meters in diameter) The outerwooden shell is a protective layer for the inner structure, composed of 18 wooden arcs and clad in wooden panels.

Kate and I made our way back to the city center after our tour, and grabbed a glass of wine at a cafe called LA CLEMENCE. So cute! This is random- but we were given a little plate of peanuts with our wine. Sometimes peanuts taste so good!! I hardly ever buy them, and if I do but nuts, I usually go for a cashew or almond variety. But peanuts can just really hit the spot sometimes. This was one of those times.

After our peanut/wine outing, we grabbed some cheese, pasta, and wine from the grocery store to cook in our arty flat. We ended up drinking the wine and eating the cheese, and not making the pasta. Sometimes that’s just how it goes around here.

The next day, we woke up, made a visit to the HALLE DE RIVE, an indoor, local food market. This place made me swoon. From the fresh meat to the freshly baked beignets, I was in food heaven.

I also made it a point to go to LADUREE, which is a famous macaroon shop based out of Paris. Salted caramel, vanilla, rose petal, mocha… they were all delicious. And who doesn’t love the presentation?!

Today’s main event was our visit to the UNITED NATIONS. It was 10 francs to tour, but really neat! We got to sit in several meeting rooms and make our way through the building learning about this specific office and how it operates. 8,000 meetings per year and over 1,600 staff members! This office is the second biggest next to the one in New York. The place was bustling with important-looking people in suits the entire time, too!

We did some more walking and exploring the rest of the afternoon. We also went to the MUSEE D’ART ET D’HISTOIRE (Art history museum). The building itself was beautiful, and actually built on what used to be a fortification ring! Rembrandt, Cezanne, Rodin, and others’ works are here, too.

We eventually made our way to the local swimming point, taking in some gorgeous views of the sunset before we were about to have the best meal of my life at LA BUVETTE DES BAINS DES PAQUIS. This restaurant does cheese fondue from September to April. Pure joy are the only words to describe it. A tub of melted cheese and bread (& wine) for dinner?? Can I do this every day please? I will attempt a re-make of this with some fondue cheese from the grocery store in a couple weeks. Perks of Swiss grocery stores.

(Oh, and did you know that when you eat cheese fondue, you are supposed to scrape the hard leftover cheese in the bottom of the pan onto your plate and eat it?? A local Genevan told us this. On account of Kate and ours was semi-burnt due to the fact that we didn’t realize we were supposed to stop the fire source ourselves, it wasn’t exactly what it was meant to be- but still yummy!! All the more excuse for me to make fondue again- so I can eat the cheese at the bottom the proper way.)

And that was Switzerland ft. Kate! I’m so lucky to have gotten to spend a week in my home away from home with my best friend. Switzerland gets even more beautiful every time I explore it.

Since being back in Mendrisio, we had a little get together in our flat on Friday night, mostly because I wanted an excuse for everyone to come over and try my favorite goodies from the US! I made funfetti cupcakes (Valentine’s Day themed with pink icing!) and set out some peanut butter m&ms and Reese’s. It’s the little things! The peanut butter m&ms were a huge hit, unsurprisingly.

And Saturday, I went to the Bellinzona Carnival! Carnival season in Europe is basically like Halloween (in the sense that everyone dresses up, Mean Girls style like Cady, not Karen), but way better. It is called Rabadan in Bellinzona, which means “noise.” This carnival is the second largest in Switzerland! (The first is Basel.) A bunch of bands paraded down the main streets and continued to play music into the night. The costumes are amazing, and so elaborate. And there is also confetti everywhere! The streets were glittered with color, wonderful music, and so many smiling faces. It was beautiful!

And classes officially start this week! And it’s been snowing! And I love Switzerland! (Even if they do take all my money.) It’s been a good couple weeks back so far 🙂

~ Haley

Let’s seeee… where was I? Amsterdam! It’s hard to believe that I’m writing about the beginning of December when it is now February… how does time pass by so fast?? Amsterdam was amazing. Let’s clear two things first: yes, it is legal to smoke weed anywhere and yes, prostitutes station themselves like mannequins in street windows in the city center. And YES this place is absolutely beautiful, and Dutch natives are probably the friendliest people I have ever met. AND YES the waffles are out of this world. Okay I’m done with the yes thing. And I know I wasn’t in Belgium, but I was still obsessed with the whole waffle scene. And I like waffles but they’re not my favorite food. (That’d be fried okra, in case you were wondering.) But I think waffles would probably be my favorite food in the Netherlands. At least that’s what my stats tell me after spending a few days there. How many times can I say the word “waffle” before people stop reading this?

So I met three of my friends there – one studying in Germany, another in Spain, and another who traveled from Tech. We didn’t have any great master plans, and had fun getting lost in a place where every street is a bridge, with some sort of picturesque, slim, post-card-looking buildings in the background. On said streets were also always 40 bikes, and 10 people whizzing by with their babies attached on some sort of seat contraption on the back. (This made me nervous, but it’s just how they roll.)

The hostel we stayed at was sooooo cooooooool. Stay here if you go! The staff is so nice, theres a cute kitchen, and the people it attracts are most likely young and looking for something/ know of something going on in the city that night. It’s called ECOMAMA.

Our first breakfast out we ate at a cute little cafe called FONTEYN, where there’s a precious cat, some good coffee and breakfast sandwiches, and a quaint atmosphere. Don’t mistake precious for nice though.. it bit my friend when she got a little too handsy.

We also went to the STEDELIJK MUSEUM, a modern art museum. The museum was beautiful! And the art was beautiful, and there were so many interactive displays and films. I definitely recommend it.

Obviously we went to the IAMSTERDAM sign. No use in pretending I’m not a tourist when I clearly am. We had some lovely background scenery, included but not limited to large electronic signs flashing: “WHITE HEROIN SOLD TO TOURISTS AS COCAINE” and “TOURISTS IN HOSPITAL – THREE HAVE DIED.”

Continuing with the tourist theme.. we went on a night time boat tour of the Amsterdam light festival! Sounds beautiful right?? Okay well I had some picturesque image in my mind, that even though it was pushing below 10 degrees with wind chill, we would be in a quaint, open-aired boat marveling at the beautiful buildings and lights reflecting on the skinny canal waters. What we got was a completely enclosed boat, with some cheap plastic material that fogged up when everyone loaded ship, plus some complimentary chex mix. Oh and we indulged in a cheap bottle of wine. Alright it wasn’t horrible, but this I do not recommend. It was still cool and I can say I did it, but we were counting down the minutes til we could hop off and go do something else.

We went out on the town a couple nights, and PARADISO was one of the places worth mentioning- it’s a multistory club housed inside of an old church. Bars, stage, music, lights – everything! It was so fun.

We went to a place that just said “PANCAKES STEAK HOUSE” for breakfast one morning… it wasn’t bad! I’d give the name a 2 and the food a 5.5.

Caitie and I ventured to the industrial side of town that day, where we looked out over the city atop the SKYLOUNGE AMSTERDAM, which is just a bar at the top of a Hilton hotel. No fees, nothing! Just head straight up to the view.

We also walked on top of NEMO, which is a science center that mimics the design of a ship.

That was basically Amsterdam.. then I headed over to DUSSELDORF, GERMANY for the night to stay with Caitie. We went to some German Christmas markets (AMAZING) and drank German beer. My stomach was delighted by the pretzels, candied nuts, beer, gluehwein (hot red wine with Christmas-y spices), potatoes, and more beer. I really don’t know how I didn’t gain 40 pounds abroad.

Back in Mendrisio… a bunch of work awaited me. The final studio push got me… real good. Continuous nights of 3 hours of sleep, a couple all-nighters, and I was toast. One night when my studio partner and I were making our model, I realized we had just glued two things together wrong, at which point I started screaming, “HELP!!! HANNAH IT’S NOT FUNNY!!!! HELP! HELP!” And then my friend (who’s studio was on the opposite side of the building) came over and said she heard me screaming from her desk. I asked if she definitely knew it was me and she was like um DUH! Of course it was you! She continued to mimic my American-sounding high-pitched cries for help. It was all worth it in the end though! I was content with the final presentation. Here are a few pictures!

In between the crazy studio stuff I found time to visit my friends in Riva to watch the Grinch and get in the Christmas spirit, and I also made it to the Lugano Christmas market one Saturday! No one wanted to go with me so I put on my big girl pants and took myself out for a nice evening. I wrote down everything I ate: Gluewhein, a weird fruity drink, raclette (cheesy bread), roasted chestnuts, hot chocolate, AND to top it off a Toblerone McFlurry from McDonalds. Also, I would like to point out that as I’m writing this post, Toblerone is underlined as being spelled wrong, while McFlurry is not. That concerns me a little bit. But I can’t really complain because the Toblerone McFlurry was out of this world.

In the days leading to my departure back to the homeland, everyone at the casa just hung out and relaxed.. which hadn’t truly happened since the very beginning of the semester. So that was nice too 🙂

And theeeeen we all know what happens next.. United States of America!! The second I arrived at my gate in Frankfurt, whose destination was New Jersey, I felt like I was already back. I happened to sit next to two gossipy girls and realized why Americans annoy Europeans. Nevertheless, it was nice to be able to actually fully understand conversations happening around you, as opposed to the random phrases I pick up on in side conversations in Italian.

And I have honestly loved being home, and am so glad I got to spend the holidays with family and friends. From Ashland to Richmond to Tennessee to Lake Gaston to Blacksburg to Charlottesville to Blacksburg again and back to Ashland, I wouldn’t have changed a thing about my time here. It’s crazy how much life gets slapped into perspective when you do things out of the ordinary, like live in Europe for 4 months. I am so thankful for this life and the family and friends I get to call mine. Here are a couple of highlights. And of course I have a Brian Andreas quote to go with it…!

Who can say that moment when Love takes the shape of the people in your days? It is a simple thing & still I have nothing to say other than Yes. That moment is who we are here to be. ~ Brian Andreas

xxoo Haley

Oh Sundayssss. I’m trying to feverishly write this blog post because I think it’s going to have to be my last one before I can write about the rest of my semester here in the comfort of my own cloud crazy comfy bed surrounded by my soft pink walls and an Anthropologie candle afire on my bedside table. I’m melting just thinking about it.

I listened to this Perfect Day song when I was running this morning, and it hasn’t left my brain since. Such a good running song. And also not a bad song to have stuck in your head when you are in studio for 6 hours trying to figure out how to build a six foot tall wooden model for your final presentation! And no, that’s no exaggeration. Praying everything fits together right at the end…!

Anyway, this post is mostly for the amazing day trip I went on yesterday with my Architecture in Ticino class- we visited three close by cities in Switzerland where some traditionally local architecture is sited, those being LOCARNO, LOSONE, and ASCONA.

We started off by stopping by a rec center named CENTRO SPORTIVO NAZIONALE DELLA GIOVENTU in TENERO designed by Mario Botta. Botta founded the academy I study at, and his buildings are literally all over the place, and you can usually spot them by their distinct brick facades. In this project, there is a large volume for the gym at the core, some changing spaces/bathrooms occupy the perimeter, and it resolves in a huge portico-type space outside. Some administration and living facilities sit adjacent to it.

Then, we had the opportunity to visit the SCUOLE MEDIE DI VIA VARESI in LOCARNO, designed by Dolf Schebli, with Ernst Engeler, Isidor Ryser, and Bernhard Meyer. It was a Saturday, so there was an administrator who let us in and explore the school. Boy is this the nicest elementary school I’ve ever been in. This design won the competition that was held for its creation, and used elements of a school designed by Walter Gropius as a part of the Architects’ Collaborative. Every classroom has its own skylight, so there was a ton of natural light. Glass doors in the hallways are able to be turned perpendicular to allow natural ventilation into the school, and everything was detailed down to the beautiful coat/ backpack hangers.

The SCUOLE ELEMENTARI AI SALEGGI DI LOCARNO was designed by Livio Vacchini and was right across the street. This one was completely different- the purpose was to integrate the school with the city. Which is kind of weird for an elementary school.. at least for me. Usually you see this with colleges in big cities. So there were many outdoor spaces and some nice courtyard-like spaces to explore. Again, there was a gym here as well. My professor explained to us that Vacchini (the architect) likes to create things which seem immediately very rational and sensical, but he likes to be somewhat unorthodox or visually deceptive upon a closer glance. For example, the gym facade looked very neo-classical, with the same repeated columns on center with a traditional portico. But, there are only 9 columns (usually there are an even number), and the middle column (which is on the same axis as the thick wall which separates the two gym spaces inside) is thicker than all of the others.

Another school we visited was the SCUOLE MEDIE DI LOSONE, designed by Livio Vacchini and Aurelio Galfetti. This school uses the city as a modular reference, as there were four big blocks of classrooms with a central courtyard, all existing within a grid. The views from the classrooms were amazing- these double-heighted rooms had such nice qualities of light and views out to the mountains and exterior courtyards/ gardens. Honestly, I think I would be a bit distracted trying to learn here! And the crazy red steel structure was a little bizarre. It was really neat being able to walk around all of these schools though, and see how they’re currently used.

We paused for lunch on LAGO MAGGIORE in ASCONA. (This is the same lake my island is located in, except way more south!) The views were amazing. I found a quote the other day I scribbled down from the book Beautiful Ruins by Jess Walter, which was “He considered it a shame when people couldn’t grasp the infinite- a failure not just of imagination but of simple vision.” The mountains here and the clear blue waters are really so amazing, and I don’t think I’ll cease to stare at them in wonder.

We then had the wonderful opportunity to tour Livio Vacchini’s house! (CASA VACCHINI) His wife and daughter showed us around, which was so sweet. This modular unit is made of steel structure and wooden infill. Modest in size, the wood infill panels are removable/ additive as need be- which I found pretty neat! The outdoor garden is almost like the most important room of the whole house- it was beautiful.

Then, there was Vacchini’s PALESTRA in LOSONE (another gym). You enter underground, to walk up the stairs and into a large, unobstructed court. There were two viewing platforms on either end, but other than that it’s just you, the structure, and the light coming through into the space! The building looks really imposing from the outside but actually really light and spacious from the inside- or so I thought.

The last two buildings were not my favorite, and designed by Vacchini in his later years, which were the EDIFICIO AMMINISTRATIVO E COMMERCIALE LA FERRIERA (an office building) and EDIFICIO POSTALE (post office), both in LOCARNO. Still, it was interesting to see this more modern approach in the city center compared to his other architecture, which is considered typically Ticinese.

So, that was 11/22/2014 in a nutshell! Beautiful day.

Oh, and the day before yesterday was the final exhibition of all my architecture friends in Riva! It was so nice to see what they’ve been working on all semester, from projects to pictures to sketches. Karaoke was sung after, etc. etc.

And other than that, work, work, work, all day long! My project in a nutshell is a proposal to provide more housing in the form of bird towers for this exotic island, as well as sculpturally and organically expand the existing reed beds around the island in the form of a fixed, movable steel system that moves with the water level. This system is proposed in response to two existing conditions, which are an overpopulation of birds and also the constantly changing water level of the lake by 3 meters (about 10 feet) throughout the year. Our final critiques are on December 16th and 17th, and then I come home on the 21st! The last few weeks of studio always go by the fastest even though you’re there more than ever.. it’s like a timeless blur of the computer screen, glue, and late night pizza (and here chocolate!!).

But this week I go to Amsterdam!! Wow can’t believe I can actually say that. I am pretty nervous to travel here to Milano to the Bergamo airport to the Netherlands all by my big girl self.. wish me safe travels please!! Until RVA…!

~ Haley

I have eaten haggis!!! (11/9/2014) Okay, so anyone who knows me in the slightest I think will view this as a huge accomplishment for me. I will enlighten you should you not know what it is (according to Wikipedia): “a savoury pudding containing sheep’s pluck (heart, liver, and lungs); minced with onion, oatmeal, suet, spices, and salt, mixed with stock and traditionally encased in the animal’s stomach and simmered for approximately three hours.” Um, I’m sorry, encased in the sheep’s stomach to cook?? It still kind of makes me cringe.. I know I am definitely a carnivore but something about this just seems especially repulsive. So, thanks to Rachael, my Scottish friend who made this Scottish delicacy, along with some other things that resembled shepherd’s pie, AKA delicious. I even had a swig of Scottish whiskey- instant body warmer-upper! Traditional Scottish meal: check.

Oh and the day before that (11/8/2014) I went to the FIERA DI SAN MARTINO. AKA a carnival!! This used to be an organized cattle market dedicated to the patron saint of St. Martin. And it still is! But what used to be strictly agricultural (selling cows and whatnot), now its fully equipped with alcohol, cotton candy, and rides. {All good things in life.} We tasted local wines of Ticino, I ate polenta with onion soup, and screamed on a fair ride like a little kid. It was awesome.

But really, nothing super exciting to report. Except that’s kind of a ridiculous thing to say because when I look back and remember that time I spent the year in Switzerland I know I’d read that sentence and be like, ugh, Haley stop. My experience here has really been amazing. I am completely immersed in European culture, as most everyone I live with is European. I get to sit in on famous architects giving critiques on students’ projects. I get to grocery shop in Italy on a regular basis. I get to have the excuse of eating way too much chocolate cuz YOISW (you’re only in Switzerland once). {I just made that up. Catchy eh?!} I get to learn how to travel internationally independently, budget, cook! I get to appreciate, even more, the things I love about my home in Virginia. Gosh I could go on and on about the “get-to’s.” Being completely removed from my home and being a long-term guest in someone else’s has proved to be such a beautiful experience for me, and it’s not even halfway over!

Anyway, here in Mendrisio there has been this thing called RAIN. And nonstop. And of course.. my Leadership in Architecture course had a site visit on (I’m pretty sure) the one day where it never, ever stopped raining at an alarmingly heavy rate. It was only three train stops away, but still. Even with my rainboots, rain jacket, and dinky Rome umbrella (okay, well that kinda doesn’t have too much to offer), I was still so uncomfortably wet the entire trip/day.
