Last weekend (10/25/2014) I went to Milan on a day trip with a few friends! (Because when you live in the Italian canton of Switzerland you can do things like take an hour train ride to the fashion capital of the world for the day. Nbd.)

Technically, I’ve been to Milano Centrale (the train station) like at least 10 times already. But I had never spent any time outside of here except to grab some food. It was so so fun to walk around and experience the city! We didn’t really have anything on the agenda, except to go to one museum in the historic city center.

Oh, and obviously I fashion-ista’d up to go! Jk, I just put on a Flash Tattoo. Yes, I said tattoo! As in those temporary Disney princess tattoos you wear when you’re five. Except these are WAY cooler (well actually that depends on my mood) and made for women. Here’s a picture of my most recent one!

They stay on for about a week or two and then just scrub off with hot water and soap. I saw them in South Moon Under before I left the country, and thought they looked so stupid, until I saw them on one of the girls working there and it was love at first sight! They have necklaces, bracelets, rings, earrings, etc.. it’s up to you to get creative with them, which is half the fun! Here’s their website if anyone’s interested 🙂

http://www.flashtat.com/

So, anyway, when we got to Milan we hopped off the train to take the subway to the Garibaldi station, where we then just wandered into the city! The first thing we saw when we walked outside was this huge, GREEN high rise building. I usually only see things like this in magazines.. it’s called BOSCO VERTICALE and, as you can see, is this huge, green high rise apartment building!! Pretty crazy huh?

Then, we stopped at a cafe where I ordered a CAFFE SHAKERATO, a common Italian coffee drink. It’s essentially cold espresso with a little water and sugar. But it was very yummy! I also don’t think I’ve mentioned.. “caffe” in Europe is espresso. Then there’s lattes and cappuccinos. American coffee does not really exist here, so when you say “caffe Americano”, it means espresso with hot water, although that isn’t really the same either because the default “coffee” at home is drip coffee. I have a feeling I’ll be a little bit of a coffee snob after spending a year in Europe.. but I will never in a million years criticize or tire of Starbuck’s pumpkin spice lattes or peppermint mochas. WHO CARES that they’re horrible for you and contain fake ingredients.. so do a million other things we eat and they taste like heaven.

A few minutes later I spy a bakery. And when I am in Italy I will not not walk into a bakery and buy something. I just went in and said.. hmm. Vorrei (I would like) uhh.. questo e questo e…. questo! E questo. E questo. This was the result, and I was very happy with my purchases.

We wandered closer to the historic city center and came upon the DUOMO. There was a huge white tarp covering the square, and tons of paint buckets with paint brushes in them- people writing, drawing, etc. anything! I decided to be SO original and write my name.

Then we headed to the MUSEO DEL NOVECENTO, or the museum of the 20th century, or the museum of modern art. A new exhibition had just opened up, on Milanese artist Yves Klein and Parisian artist Lucia Fontana, and how they were both integral figures in the modern art movement in their respective regions. There was a huge installation of blue pigment (this was Klein’s “thing” this blue pigment, blue pigment on a canvas, on a body, on a sculpture, in 3d) that was part of the exhibition. By the time we got to this part of the exhibit, there were two little footprints in the pigment and then a trail of blue footprints… It made walking through the rest of the museum so amusing because you could see these faint little blue spots EVERYWHERE.

By the time we finished here, I was sooo hungry. One of my friends had a recommendation from a friend about a good aperitivo place. We took the subway a few stops and arrived at BHANGRABAR. You got your choice of cocktail and endless food for 10 euros. I took a mojito (VERY strong by the way) and hmm.. food.. quinoa, french fries, tomato salad, pizza, two different types of pasta, puff pastries, seafood, tuna salad, brownies, nutella… the list goes on.

The school week went by as fast as all the other ones (um I can’t believe I only have 6 weeks left??!) and today (11/2/2014) we went to Como again. Always a good stand-by/ day trip when you don’t have anything planned! It is All-Saints Day here so everything in Switzerland was closed, but Como was just as bustling as ever on this beautiful, sunny day! Italy how I adore you so!

Again, no real plans here- we just walked around! So much window shopping here is killing me. I have not given in to the temptation yet, but who knows how long I’ll last! I had done some research before we left on pizzerias and led my friends to a place about a 15 minute walk from the city center. (With the app CITYMAPS2GO, I’m a pro navigator. Without it, don’t ask me anything about anywhere.) We ate at PIZZERIA TRATTORIA DA BENITO, and it was sooo good. I had the proscuitto and mushroom pizza, which was simply divine and so filling.

Following, we walked back towards Lake Como and stumbled upon LA TERME DI COMO ROMANA, or a parking garage where, when they started digging into the ground, discovered some ancient Roman ruins {a thermal bath specifically}. It was pretty cool, plus the facade of the parking garage was this copper-like material with small, punched openings. It isn’t often you can say, “hey that parking garage looks cool!” But this guy was definitely one of them.

When we got back by the lake we discovered another outdoor market (we’d been running into them all day). But this one was food exclusively. I grabbed two bottles of wine and then started asking the meat guys questions, and before I knew it I was tasting like five different salamis and meats (remember, I had just eaten a whole pizza) and walked away with half a fresh Italian salami 🙂

Then we went to the grocery store.. are we noticing a pattern here people?? Where I bought two more bottles of wine, some chicken (because meat is so pricey in Svizzera), some salad and granola.

There was a bunch of stuff in between, but mostly just wondering around the city, people watching, and window shopping! It really was such a nice day, this day.

Once we got back (oh, we also got supplies to make sushi tonight while we were out) I helped my Belgian friend prepare sushi and roll it!! So, now I know how to make sushi, as taught by a Belgian. I am definitely going to try to do this when I am home.. it was actually so easy!! A little time consuming, but so much fun.

No Halloween for me this year… they do the whole pumpkin and fall-y decorating thing here, but not so much the dress up thing. BUT you guys be on the lookout for February, when the Bellinzona carnival happens. Apparently this huge festival lasts a week long and everyone dresses up, so it’s essentially Halloween in February and you can betcha I’ll be in attendance.

Happy NOVEMBER everyone!!

~ Haley

Before I go into yet another discourse on my eating habits.. Okay let’s see.. Germany! We had a very tightly packed schedule in our 1.5 days in Munich. It started with a 5.5 hour car ride with four Portugese friends, and my first German meal was at a McDonalds! Woohoo! I tried to ask for ranch with my McNuggets… definitely unsuccessful and resulted in a salty cashier attendant. (Also, the nuggets did taste a little different, more bland, and the fries tasted the same.) We get to the hostel a little before 12, and we are staying at HI MUNICH PARK HOSTEL. This time, it was real!! None of that fake Rome stuff. Plus, breakfast was included for real this time!!

Our travels!! This is really history rich and much to do with postwar architecture since uh.. that’s why I came!!

First day 10/10/14

We went to CHURCH ST. BONIFAZ.

It was founded by Ludwig I in 1835, and completed by architect Georg Friedrich Ziebland in 1850. The church was heavily damaged in WWII and a reconstruction of the church was completed by Hans Dollgast beginning 1945 through 1952. We paid specific attention to the reconstructed part, which took place towards the end of the nave/ beginning of the transept.

Then we walked over to ALTE PINAKOTHEK, an art gallery that was originally designed by Leo von Klenze in the beginning of the 19th century, and then restored after the war by Hans Dollgast. If you’re noticing a pattern here, he was really popular for his “creative reconstruction” works during the post-war period. Damaged and missing parts of this building weren’t imitated to look like the rest, but reconstructed in a modern style that used the bricks of previously destroyed buildings during the war.

The KONIGSPLATZ was Ludwig I’s idea of all realms of life- cultural, civic, an religious- embedded in a picturesque green context. It was designed by Leo von Klenze in 1816, but was used during the Third Reich as a rally point for the Nazis. The entire square was plastered over with granite, to hold huge ceremonies and marches through the center of town. The Nazi headquarters was held just across the street at the BROWN HOUSE.

We walked over to the Brown House, and in front of it is a new building under construction called the NS DOCUMENT CENTER, designed by Georg Scheel Wetzel Architekten. A local professor gave us some background history of the area and showed us through the building! He told us that even though Berlin became the political center of the Nazi party during the war, Munich was always the capital of the Nazi movement. After WWII, a lot of the Nazi artifacts and buildings began to hide under overgrown vegetation, and it hasn’t been until relatively recently that people have decided to really uncover these places and decide how to deal with them. The new building, located near 4 major historical sites relating to Nazi history, has openings on various levels that frame a view to the corresponding historically significant site, housing exhibitions and information regarding the place in view as you move through the museum.

We paid a visit to the GLYPTOTHEK, which houses many ancient sculptures, ranging from the archaic era to the Roman era. (This is located in Konigsplatz.) This museum was also commissioned by Ludwig I, designed by Leo von Klenz and built in the early 19th century. Walking through the museum was an effortless movement from one space to the next- it was a beautiful exhibition!

We grabbed lunch at HAMBURGEI, where I had a deeeeelicious Bavarian hamburger and some German Coca Cola! Now that’s what I call a pretzel buns, my friends.

We walked by the AMERIKAHAUS, which was a program developed after WWII, operated by the United States, that gave German and Austrian citizens the opportunity to learn more about American politics and culture.

We had the opportunity to visit the ODEON, which was a former concert hall, and now services an office building. This space was really unique! Again designed by Leo von Klenze, it was almost completely destroyed in the war and rebuilt after. The hall consists of two superimposed colonnades, reaching a height of 50 feet. Now, it is an interior courtyard, and the ceiling (which was originally decorated with elaborate frescoes) exists as a glazed roof designed by Ackermann and Partner. The quality of light and atmosphere here was really soothing to me for some reason- our class spent about 30 minutes in this courtyard, looking around at the wall sculptures and up at diffuse light coming in through the lattice ceiling structure.

We then walked by the RESIDENZ (ROYAL CASTLE) which is really in the heart of the city center. This was the royal palace of the Bavarian monarchs, and it is now the largest city palace in Germany. We didn’t go inside, but the thing was huge! Apparently it has ten courtyards within the building and 130 rooms. Around the palace there were a bunch of cafes and people playing something that looked similar to Bocce Ball.

We then made our way to the HAUS DER KUNST, which was commissioned by Hitler in 1933 and designed by Paul Ludwig Troost. This was the first monumental Nazi architecture, and was meant to house the art that only Hitler thought Germany should accept and support as a part of their culture. Across the street in 1937, there was a Degenerate art exhibition held in which all modern art was plastered on the walls and written on with heinous phrases dismissing the artwork. Hitler also gave many speeches in the main hall here. After the war, American forces occupied the building, even using the bar in the back as a place to socialize. (It still exists today!) Now, it is home to only modern art exhibitions. Our guide of the building noted that the heightened, monumental, totalitarian feel of the building was an ideal condition for displaying many forms of modern art. There really are still such strong feelings regarding the reuse or remembrance of Nazi buildings, and that became very evident upon actually visiting all of these places.

The last stop of the day was the OLYMPIC STADIUM, designed by Gunther Behnisch and engineer Frei Otto for the 1972 Summer Olympics. And it was beautiful at sunset! The thing you notice first is definitely the large, fluid acrylic glass that soars over the stadium, anchored to the ground by steel cables. This light, airy construction was meant to be a gesture towards the new German government, optimistic and forward-looking. The official motto was actually “The Happy Games.” The facility was used later for several other matches, but the soccer players began to complain that they really couldn’t compete in this space because of its light, open, and fluid nature. It apparently didn’t foster enough of a competitive environment, which makes sense on account of that’s not what the design was trying to do!

We also passed by BMW WORLD on the way out, so we had a look inside! Although, surprise surprise, I’m not too big on staring at fancy cars unless I’m about to drive one away, so we only stayed for a bit. We did, however, study this building in my environmental building systems class last year because of its play on artificial light with daylight, natural ventilation, heating, and cooling. I do recall being comfortable in terms of body temperature and atmosphere, so all in all it was a successful drive-by. (Get my play on words there??)

Some more pictures of Germany:

Second day 10/11/2014

This was a rather heavy-hearted day, as we only made 2 stops: The JUDISCHES ZENTRUM (A Jewish centre with a synagogue, museum, and community center) and the GEDENKSTATTE KZ DACHAU (the concentrations camp).

The synagogue in ST. JAKOBS PLATZ was beautiful. The quality of light and space was breathtaking.

The museum was so interesting. The main focus of the museum concerned itself with the Jewish in Germany beginning with WWI, the progressive attitude of Germans toward the Jewish, as well as the cultural and familial aspects of Jews living in Germany. No pictures were allowed of the exhibit, but we spent a good hour and half or two making our way through the exhibition.

It then took us about a 40 minute train ride and a 15 minute bus ride to arrive at the Dachau concentration camp. I don’t really feel the need to give too much historical background regarding this site, but being here felt very surreal. It was interesting to read signs posted throughout the camp with specifics regarding daily life and functions of specific places- things I hadn’t read in textbooks before. There were also three new constructions built on the camp, which are: the JEWISH MEMORIAL, the CATHOLIC MORTAL AGONY OF CHRIST CHAPEL, and the PROTESTANT CHURCH OF RECONCILIATION. It was interesting to see how architects chose to approach this site, for example, the chapel was placed along the strong existing axes of the camp, while the protestant church contained no right angles to break from the rigidity of the original plan, and descends into part of the earth to further break the camp grounds.

Before we left the city,we ventured back on our own through the city center again, making sure to stop by a gelato place called BALLA BENI, which was recommended to me by one of my friends who is a German exchange student here and studies in Munich. Five words: yum yum yum yum and yum. The flavors were really unique!! I had chocolate ginger and maroni, with a “taste” (they give you an extra spoon of something to try- why hasn’t this been adopted by ice cream servers worldwide??) of the basil lemon.

We then took a stroll through the ENGLISH GARDEN, which was absolutely amazing!! Essentially, it’s the Central Park of Munich, but bigger! So many people were out on this sunny Sunday afternoon. I think we walked a little over a mile before reaching the CHINESISCHER TURM (Chinese Tower) where the happiest place on earth was: the beer garden! As soon as I saw this tower, equipped with traditional Bavarian musicians on the second level, my immediate first thought was: THIS LOOKS EXACTY LIFE BUSCH GARDENS! Well done, Busch Gardens. Feels like I’m in Williamsburg, only I know I won’t be stoping for Pierces BBQ on the way home. It was too bad we had too leave before we could enjoy one of those liters of beer… Munich, I’ll be back!

Week of 10/13/2014

~Normal, run-of-the-mill stuff, folks! I’m studying abroad so I do work here from time to time.

~Still finding it hard to practice/learn Italian because English is the language spoken where I live among all of the exchange students.

~Went to Lugano last Tuesday to a bar called COYOTE UGLY, which then sparked the idea to sing “Can’t Fight the Moonlight” at karaoke on Friday night in Riva. It was also 3 for 10 CHF tequila shots!

~Had a critique on Thursday, we are in the process of designing a bird observatory for researchers around our island- Isolina Partegora.

~Visited our site on Friday, which is located in ANGERA, ITALY. It took two trains and a bus to get there, but the town was beautiful! It’s so fun researching something so fully, looking at creepy street views and photographs of a place, and feeling like you’ve actually already been there, before you actually go and visit! (When we got there I had salame piccante pizza for lunch at the restaurant in HOTEL PAVONE. No shame that I finished the whole thing- it was so so good.) We took some time to walk along the inlet that surrounds the town, of LAGO MAGGIORE. Our island is really small, about 3500 square meters, and not really accessible to people, due to the exotic birds and wildlife that have claimed the island as home. Our job is to figure out how/where to build our observatory for the island. Visiting made me so much more excited to get moving with the project! It also wasn’t terrible that we found a local bakery, where I got an assortment of desserts and proceeded to eat them all within the minute.

~This past Saturday, the international office here at the university offered to pay for our travel and lunch to visit BELLINZONA, which is the capital of TICINO, the province of Switzerland where I live. We started the Saturday off early and were greeted by our tour guide in Bellinzona at CASTELGRANDE. The Castle sits on a huge rock. It was built in the late 14th century and occupied by the Sforza dukes of Milan until the 15th century. There is a rich history of the Italian rule and the Swiss interest in the area, ultimately ending with the Swiss (obviously) conquering Bellinzona, essentially creating the Ticinese part of Switzerland, or the Italian part of Switzerland. Pizza for lunch, coffee after…. a usual meal here in Italian Switzerland. Myself and a couple friends ventured around Bellinzona and the next closest mountain village, called MONTE CARASSO from late afternoon until evening. The night ended with having aperitvo and listening to a live band, all with the Swiss Alps in the background! It was a pretty successful day, and it was so nice to be a tourist of a nearby place that is very culturally significant and relevant to my small town of Mendrisio!

~ The highlight of my Sunday was traveling to IPER with my Riva friends and former professor. They have a van, which we drove in for about 15 minutes before arriving at the Walmart equivalent in Italy. Basically everything is more expensive in Switzerland, but the highlights of my purchases included (but were not limited to): Italian meat kebabs, 1 euro bread loafs, 2 euro fresh pizza dough, body wash, nutella, apples, cauliflower, and parmesan cheese. Oh, and pasta is dirt cheap (in Switzerland, too, but especially in Italy). I’ll be able to look back on my abroad experience.. remember when I ate pasta every day and a pounds of chocolate every week? Also.. my four types of extra virgin olive oils: a cheap one for cooking things on the stove, my really nice one from Florence, a middle-of-the road one that I got when I first got here, and a new, nicer olive oil from Iper. Extra virgin olive oil is my jam. I love it so much. And grocery shopping is seriously one of my favorite things to do here. Although.. sometimes the whole everything-being-in-Italian thing throws me off. I know I’ll be excited to walk into a Kroger at home and actually 100% understand what I am buying.. but til then I’m perfectly happy buying Italian meets, cheeses, and wines because usually, you can’t go too wrong!

AND FINALLY I think I have successfully recapped the last 10 days or so.

Xxoo Haley

7. Last but not least, Brian Andreas is always the answer!! He actually just finished a new book recently called Something Like Magic (on remembering how to be alive). This is an part of his introduction to his book that he posted online:

“Each one {all his little stories} is something like magic, because all it takes is a moment of remembering them & suddenly the whole world sparkles again. The funny thing is it never stopped sparkling. We just stopped seeing it, because it was too simple & we were convinced it must be something different. We let ourselves be convinced the most important thing was something different than the love & magic that’s been here all along.

I sat in the garden that night & I thought about the most important thing for me. That we love & are loved. All the time, in every moment, no matter how it looks to other eyes that don’t remember quite yet. That’s why I think remembering is one of the most important things we can do right now. It’s how we stop & see the world again for the very first time. In all of its aching beauty & join & pain. The immensity of all of it. It’s how we open to being loved wildly & deliciously until we are filled beyond anything we ever thought we could hold.

I hope the stories here are a reminder to you. A reminder to stop & see the world again for the very first time. When you do & one day not long after, your most important thing ripples through you like an immense wave of light, I hope you’ll see why I say it’s something like magic. Because you’ll see it’s been there all along in the heart of you, waiting for you to remember you’re alive now & everything you are is Love.

But, like I said, you already know that…”

~Brian Andreas
